text: so I'm here in a pari in the north of
the Philippines it's the area where
forecasters believe the super typhoon
will hit hardest when it makes landfall
in the coming days it's quite windy here
at the moment the waves are quite high
but what we've heard is that when it
really hits it will bring storm surges
of around two storeys tall this is a
small town a low-rise town and I've been
speaking to some of the residents here
about how they feel about the storm they
say that they've been through this
before they've seen other storms they
said that they have been taught by local
councilors and police to move on and
that there's an evacuation center just
500 meters down the road now we've also
been speaking to people who've been
putting rocks and tying their roofs down
onto heavy boulders to try to prevent
their roofs from flying off when the
storm comes some people have even said
that they want to stay inside the
property to make sure that thieves don't
enter their homes to take their goods
and belongings and we've seen other
people moving away from the area on the
way in we saw cars leaving with bedding
on the roof we also saw farmers on the
outskirts of this small town who were
harvesting around the pot to try to get
as much of the rice from their paddies
as they can before this storm comes in
and potentially devastates their fields
they're giving everything I've seen it's
somewhat alarming that there is a bigger
presence by the local authorities here
telling people to move on it seems that
people here are very relaxed with the
idea that a super typhoon is coming
their way
